competitive_intel:
## Available Competitive Intelligence

- Competition description: `../research/description.md`
- 5 top kernel notebooks in `../research/kernels/`

data_findings.finding: This is a 2D packing optimization problem: fit Christmas tree toys (polygon shapes) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum(s_n^2/n) where s_n is side length for n trees. Lower is better. Target score: 68.922808

Tree geometry: 15-vertex polygon with trunk (0.15w x 0.2h), base (0.7w), mid (0.4w), top (0.25w), tip at y=0.8. Trees can be rotated (angle in degrees) and positioned (x,y coordinates). Collision detection uses Shapely with point-in-polygon and segment intersection tests.

Key technique: bbox3 C++ optimizer - uses simulated annealing with moves: translate, rotate, swap. Multi-phase approach: short runs to find promising (n,r) parameters, then medium/long runs on best candidates. Uses fix_direction to optimize global rotation of entire configuration.

Key technique: fix_direction - optimizes global rotation angle of entire tree configuration to minimize bounding box. Uses scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar on convex hull points. Can reduce score by finding better axis alignment.

Key technique: Backward propagation - start from N=200 and work backwards, removing boundary-touching trees one at a time to potentially improve smaller N configurations. Trees touching bounding box boundary are candidates for removal.

C++ optimizer features: squeeze (scale all trees toward center), compaction (move trees toward center), local search (8-directional moves + rotations), swap moves between tree pairs. Uses OpenMP for parallelization. Long double precision for accuracy.

Greedy initialization: Place trees one at a time, starting far from center at weighted random angle (favoring diagonal directions), move toward center until collision, then back up. Use previous N-tree config as starting point for N+1.
